title-group.article-title: Birth Tourism is Associated with Fewer Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Admissions: a Healthy Migrant Effect?

article-meta.aff: 1Neonatal-Perinatal Medicine Division, Children’s Hospital of Orange County, Orange, California, USA.
2Division of Neonatology, Pomona Valley Hospital Medical Center, Pomona, California, USA.
3Institute for Clinical and Translational Science, University of California Irvine, Irvine, California, USA.

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Jina Lim, MD, Neonatal-Perinatal Medicine Division, Children’s Hospital of Orange County, 1201 W La Veta Ave, Orange, CA, 92868. USA, Tel: +1-714-509-3096, Fax: +1-714-509-7800, jlim@choc.org

fn.p: Dr. Lim contributed to the conceptualization and design of the study, the collection, analysis, and interpretation of the data. She drafted the initial manuscript and approved the final manuscript as submitted.

Disclosure The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To study perinatal, maternal and neonatal characteristics of birth tourism (BT) mother-baby dyads and the rate of neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admissions of BT infants.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Retrospective study at a regional perinatal center comparing BT mother-baby dyads to all dyads. BT infants admitted to the NICU were compared to a randomly selected group of infants admitted to the NICU during the same time period.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: 1,755 BT dyads were identified over four years. BT mothers were older (32 vs. 28 years, p < 0.0001), more likely to carry multiples (5.5 vs. 1.4%, p < 0.0001), deliver via cesarean section (40 vs. 34%, p < 0.0001) and require post-partum intensive care (0.6% vs. 0.1%, p < 0.0001). BT infants had significantly fewer NICU admissions 96 (5.5%) vs. 3 213 (11.3%) (p< 0.0001). There were no statistically significant differences in NICU course and outcome between BT and non-BT control infants.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Birth tourism is associated with unique determinants of health. In our study there were fewer NICU admissions, potentially explained by the healthy migrant effect.
